nytimes_articles.headline: Restaurants
nytimes_articles.abstract: Like a long-running Broadway show, Orso has remained vital and fresh despite many cast changes over the years. This offshoot of the Joe Allen empire opened in 1985 when Restaurant Row on West 46th Street seemed headed toward gastronomic senescence. Almost single-handedly, Orso brought back the Broadway movers and shakers, instilling new life into the block.   Orso's step-down main dining room is dominated by a high arching skylight that creates a cheerful, sunny setting at lunch; in the evening it creates a sense of spaciousness. Soft ocher tones and wood trim contribute to a casual, contemporary setting. Walls are covered with publicity photographs of sports and entertainment celebrities. In the back an open tile-and-steel kitchen churns out pizzas, pastas and appealing grilled fare.

nytimes_articles.headline: Builder of Parade Floats Puts World on Wheels
nytimes_articles.abstract: IF IT'S Friday, this must be Bob DeVito's garage, where the parade floats go when they are not rolling along some avenue somewhere. Memorial Day, Wayne, N.J. Tomorrow, Montclair, N.J. Sunday, the Bronx. Next week, Fifth Avenue.   Mr. DeVito's garage, on a long street of warehouses and old factories, is like a back lot in Hollywood, but on wheels. Somewhere in this Styrofoam-and-papier-mache fantasy land, he's got the whole world on a float. New York to Moscow? It only takes a few seconds when the ocean is globs of blue paint.

nytimes_articles.abstract: Akafist, an 18-voice male chamber choir from Moscow, will give a concert on Sunday at 4 P.M. at Trinity Church, Broadway at Wall Street in lower Manhattan. nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: When LEANZA CORNETT was crowned Miss America 1993 in September, she vowed to talk about AIDS at her appearances during the year. Since then, she has learned that not everyone wants her to talk about the disease, in particular not to schoolchildren.    On Tuesday, for example, she was scheduled to speak at three elementary schools and one high school in Bradford County in north central Florida. But a week ago, she said, "I received a letter saying that the school board had asked I not mention the word AIDS or talk about it or sex, but that I talk only about self-esteem and saying no to drugs."

nytimes_articles.headline: Let's Introduce Some Common Sense Into Our Drug Policies
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Some drug legalization proponents suggest that anyone who opposes legalization must support all the foolish and ineffective drug-war policies pursued by the last two administrations: eradication of foreign drug crops, massive spending to interdict drug smuggling and draconian sentences for minor-league drug dealers.   It is strange to find A. M. Rosenthal in "Dismantling the War" (column, May 18) using the same twisted logic to argue that anyone, even the Attorney General, who opposes foolish and ineffective drug-war policies must support drug legalization. Not so.

nytimes_articles.headline: Perot Parades a Republican But Is Mum on Endorsement
nytimes_articles.abstract: Ross Perot's Texas organization called a news conference today, put Mr. Perot and Kay Bailey Hutchison, the Republican Senate candidate, on the same stage, and announced its members' support for her in the election on Saturday. Then the organization took pains to emphasize that this was not an endorsement of her.   Bill Walker, the Texas director of United We Stand America Inc., said the announcement that the group's members were supporting Mrs. Hutchison was based on a questionnaire mailed to the Texas membership of the group that Mr. Perot formed after his independent bid for President last year.

nytimes_articles.headline: Plastic Goes in the Oven and Diamond Comes Out
nytimes_articles.abstract: By cooking plastic in an ordinary oven, scientists at Pennsylvania State University seem to have achieved the chemical equivalent of making a silk purse out of a sow's ear: They have made a form of diamond.   Whether their instant diamond mix proves to have practical uses, the scientists believe they have hit upon a novel method for arranging the carbon atoms in a polymer that mimics the carbon structure of crystalline diamond. When this polymer is cooked at a relatively low temperature, it is largely converted to diamond.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dole Waves G.O.P. Flag in California
nytimes_articles.abstract: He has tempered his criticism of President Clinton with words of encouragement. He has held his fire when asked about the President's wife. But he has allowed himself a sly haircut joke or two.   On a three-day fund-raising and morale-boosting tour of California, Bob Dole, the Senate minority leader, has offered the balm of professionalism to a shaken state Republican Party, urging members to focus on the issues that unite rather than divide them.

nytimes_articles.headline: Priest Plans a Hunger Strike To Force Meeting With Bishop
nytimes_articles.abstract: A suspended Episcopal priest said yesterday that he intends to go on a hunger strike at the diocesan office this morning until Bishop Richard F. Grein meets with him to discuss the suspension. His supporters also vowed to continue their protests until he is reinstated, defying the Bishop's insistence that the protests end before any discussions take place.   The Rev. nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Art; Abstract Expressionism: The Lighter, Quieter Side
nytimes_articles.abstract: Anyone who still thinks of Abstract Expressionism strictly as bullish, monumental painting created by disaffected male heroes can think again. The Metropolitan Museum of Art's "Abstract Expressionism: Works on Paper," an exhibition drawn entirely from the museum's own collection, is so full of intimate, small-scale incident that it suggests a different sensibility altogether, one in which a supposed compulsion for self-expression is tempered by a concern for nature, for non-Western art, and for the emotional impact of sheer formal beauty.    Not that the old view is entirely wrong. Of the show's 19 artists, only two are women, and a few of the works included are aggressive in the extreme. Among them is a pair of Willem de Kooning's images of women done in oils. One dated 1950 is spiky and keen, the woman's smiling mouth cut from a cigarette ad. The other, from 1966, is a weird Rubenesque knot of blood-red and flesh-pink. Disturbingly, it suggests a kind of slashing sexual martyrdom and shows how Mr. de Kooning, uniquely among his peers at this period, found a metaphor for carnality in paint.

nytimes_articles.headline: Musty Academic Speculation or Blueprint for Political Action?
nytimes_articles.abstract: Historically, most law review articles are neither little noted nor long remembered, except by the professors who wrote them and the committees who control their futures. In the failed nomination of Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court, they were merely a contributing factor.

nytimes_articles.headline: Laoretti Is Struggling To Regain His Stroke
nytimes_articles.abstract: Larry Laoretti went from club pro to overnight hero last year when he scored his first victory on the Senior PGA Tour in the Senior United States Open.    Laoretti, from Mahopac, N.Y., played pretty well for about a month after his triumph, but his game has since declined. In 14 events this season, Laoretti's best finish has been a tie for 10th at the Bell Atlantic Classic, two weeks ago.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Day at Bergdorf's Just for the Fun of It
nytimes_articles.abstract: I MISS the violets on the Bonwit Teller bag. Not to mention the three-tiered Lenox candy dishes B. Altman used to sell. Go ahead, scoff. No one even eats candy anymore. But in this era of diminishing department stores, I'm feeling sentimental.   I know I'm partly to blame for their demise. Like millions of other people, I've become a devoted catalogue shopper, ordering everything by phone, from dishes to shoes. On Saturday afternoons, the last thing I want to do is fight the midtown crowds. Once you learn to shop lying down, it's too hard to get up again.

nytimes_articles.headline: Cherokee Run Draws Rail for A Big Belmont
nytimes_articles.abstract: Twenty years after her legendary colt, Secretariat, won the Belmont Stakes by 31 lengths, Penny Tweedy fished into the silver bowl yesterday and drew the numbered chips that assigned post positions for the 125th running of the Belmont Stakes tomorrow. She handed the first number to Bruce Lombardi, the racing secretary, who announced: "No. 1 post. Cherokee Run."   That was fine with Cherokee Run, a speed horse who would now be able to spring from the starting gate and rocket straight ahead while everybody else scrambled to catch him or at least crowd him on the rail. And, if he could keep rocketing for a mile and a half, which is a pretty big "if," then he might just make some racing history by winning the $500,000 Belmont Stakes, the third and most demanding race in the Triple Crown series.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Solingen Tragedy
nytimes_articles.abstract: Only days after the Bonn Parliament yielded to pressure from the right by scrapping Germany's liberal asylum laws, extremists stepped up their campaign against foreigners. Five Turkish women and children died in a firebombing ascribed to neo-Nazi skinheads. The Solingen tragedy, the worst of its kind since unification in 1990, ignited violent demonstrations by Turkish immigrants. Yet Chancellor Helmut Kohl's generalized condemnation of all violence does not begin to deal with the valid grievances of a vulnerable minority.   Germany's 1.5 million or so Turkish inhabitants are not asylum-seekers fleeing persecution at home. Nearly all are guest workers, or the offspring of guest workers, whose toil has been an essential element in Germany's "economic miracle." However, few are citizens, hardly any are civil servants and none sit in the national Parliament.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sounds Around Town
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jeff Harnar on Hollywood   Jeff Harnar, "Dancing in the Dark: Vincente Minnelli's Hollywood," the Oak Room at the Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street, Manhattan, (212) 840-6800. In a show that is a model of its type, Jeff Harnar pays tribute to the celebrated movie director by blending biographical anecdotes with astutely chosen songs from the 14 movie musicals Minnelli directed. A smooth pop baritone who suggests a hybrid of Larry Kert and Johnny Mathis, Mr. Harnar hits a peak in a rock-and-roll-flavored medley of songs with celestial themes. Show time is 9:30 tonight and tomorrow. At the club's 11:30 P.M. late shows, Mr. Harnar is also performing his equally delightful program "The 1959 Broadway Songbook." For each show there is a $25 music charge and a $10 food-and-drink minimum.  The Three Faces of Betty    Betty, the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, Chelsea, (212) 244-3005. A musical-comedy trio featuring Alyson Palmer and the sisters Amy and Bitzy Ziff, Betty is as smart and funny as it is stylistically uncategorizable. Short sketches, commentary and news media satire with a feminist slant are blended with original songs into a continuous stream of music and talk. The musical elements include cello, train whistle, bass and electric keyboard. Performance art meets cabaret meets rock with a hint of funk. Show times are tonight and tomorrow at 9 and 11:15, and tickets are $25 and $20.

nytimes_articles.headline: 3 Candidates Striving to Leave No Republican Unturned
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jim Wallwork came here to greet noontime shoppers and noshers around the Morristown Green today at a campaign stop that showed the difficulties of winning votes in the Republican primary for governor.   He shook the hands of Democrats. He shook the hands of independents. He even shook the hands of a few of New Jersey's 799,000 Republicans, who make up only about 20 percent of the state's 3.9 million registered voters.

nytimes_articles.headline: Crash Kills Cyclist On Lower East Side
nytimes_articles.abstract: A 22-year-old man who was on his way to buy a soda was killed early yesterday morning when a car ran a red light and rammed into the bicycle he was riding on the Lower East Side, the police said.   The victim, Emilio Rodriguez, had just left his home at 610 East 11th Street and was heading around the corner to a bodega when he was struck at the intersection of 10th Street and Avenue B.

nytimes_articles.headline: Art in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dario Urzay  Pamela Auchincloss Gallery 558 Broadway (near Prince Street) SoHo Through June 30   Sealed beneath shiny layers of varnish, pale clouds of color drift across Dario Urzay's canvases. Mr. Urzay, a Spanish painter who lives in New York City, uses cosmetics as pigments, and as a result his palette runs to pastel pinks, pale greens and tawny browns with a few fiery reds and metallic golds thrown in.

nytimes_articles.headline: Good With Violins, Not With People
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Un Coeur en Hiver" ("A Heart in Winter"), a coolly elegant romance directed by Claude Sautet, is centered on Stephane (Daniel Auteuil), who is solemn and expert when it comes to his craft (repairing fine violins) but has no skill in matters of emotion.    There is a certain irony to this film's title. Stephane is hardly more wintry-hearted than the story's other two principals, with whom he becomes involved in a subtle and difficult romantic triangle. Each of these refined, self-involved characters has his or her own form of chilly isolation, but it is Stephane who pays most noticeably for his shortcomings.

nytimes_articles.headline: Backing Away Again, Christopher Says Bosnia Is Not a Vital Interest
nytimes_articles.abstract: Taking another step back from the war in Bosnia, Secretary of State Warren Christopher said today that the conflict "involves our humanitarian concerns, but it does not involve our vital interests."   The end of the cold war, Mr. Christopher said, has changed the stakes in such conflicts and is a primary reason the Clinton Administration has failed to persuade its European allies to follow its lead on Bosnia.

nytimes_articles.headline: Raiders to Rocket: Let's Talk
nytimes_articles.abstract: Toronto Argonauts receiver RAGHIB (ROCKET) ISMAIL will be in California this weekend to meet with Los Angeles Raiders' officials and work out for the team's coaching staff.   "We haven't talked about a specific amount or the number of years," said BOB WOOLF, Ismail's agent. "But if they like him and they put forth an offer that I like, then anything is possible."

nytimes_articles.headline: TV Weekend; An Uneasy Pair: Business and Politics
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Washington Under the Influence" is the first of four programs on the uneasy relationship between business and politics. Evidently under the influence of the admirable Fred Friendly seminars, the new series, "On the Issues," brings together players from Government, corporate board rooms and elsewhere to be badgered by an immoderate sort of moderator about a hypothetical problem that reflects problems that are only too real.   Tonight's hypothetical, advanced by Jeff Greenfield of ABC News, has to do with a small furniture company that is under attack by workers and environmentalists for using chemicals that cause chronic fatigue syndrome. Lending themselves to the exercise are lobbyists, legislators, business executives and journalists, generously lumped together by John Chancellor, who introduces each hour, as "distinguished leaders."

nytimes_articles.headline: 20 Years After, Foreman Is Again Stalking a Title
nytimes_articles.abstract: George Foreman stopped sparring long enough to give a lesson in syntax. He was surprised at reports he would retire after his fight Monday against Tommy Morrison for the vacant World Boxing Organization heavyweight crown.   "I only said, 'This will probably be the last time you'll see me in the ring,' " Foreman said. He paused, and added, "But I never said I was going to retire."

nytimes_articles.headline: Article 315693 -- No Title
nytimes_articles.abstract: For eight years, Wilson's was a popular restaurant and thriving singles bar on the Upper West Side. Then, earlier this year, it closed down for six weeks to renovate the dining room and kitchen. When it reopened in April, it had a new menu and a new name, Chaz & Wilson Grill.   To some, this blurring of a successful identity might be marketing suicide. To Debbie Wilson, a co-owner, it was sound strategy in the increasingly competitive Upper West Side restaurant business centering on Amsterdam Avenue in the low 80's.

nytimes_articles.headline: Man in the News; The Mercurial Prince: Norodom Sihanouk
nytimes_articles.abstract: He was a King when he was 18, a prisoner at 20, an exile at 31, a Prime Minister at 32, a chief of state again at 38, a prisoner again at 54, an exile again at 69.   Now, at 70, Norodom Sihanouk has once again come to the brink of power, and characertistically pulled back, at least for the moment. His approach to the situation appears to be not much different from what it was in the days when his business cards simply said, "Sihanouk du Cambodge," Sihanouk of Cambodia.

nytimes_articles.headline: Art in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Richard Prince  Barbara Gladstone Gallery 99 Greene Street (near Prince Street) SoHo Through June 12   The women in Richard Prince's blowups of snapshots taken from motorcycle magazines are both creepy and pathetic. Draping themselves nude over the seats of their boyfriends' bikes or posing in dark glasses and leopardskin tights, they seem to want to embody defiant fantasies of sexual outrageousness.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.N. Press Corps Put Strain on Diplomacy
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Re "Dumb Censorship at the U.N." (editorial, May 26): The invitation by the United Nations correspondents to Shen Tong, a leading Chinese dissident, to meet with them in their club led a member state of the United Nations, China, to protest to Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali what it considered a political activity at odds with its standing as a member state of the world organization.   The club of the United Nations Correspondents Association is inside the Secretariat building. Imagine, for example, if the National Press Club were at the Department of State building. This imposes certain limitations on the use that may be made of such space, in contrast to situations where journalists' associations occupy independent quarters.

nytimes_articles.headline: Stemming Slaughter in the Streets
nytimes_articles.abstract: The gun lobby is finally losing its grip on America. Despite heavy lobbying by the National Rifle Association, two states -- New Jersey and Virginia -- have placed limits on sales of assault weapons within their borders. Connecticut is on the verge of doing the same.    Now a survey by Louis Harris shows that Americans as a whole approve of stringent weapons control to stem the rising tide of handgun deaths.

nytimes_articles.headline: Guinier Had to Go. Now.
nytimes_articles.abstract:
President Clinton's withdrawal of the nomination of Lani Guinier as Assistant Attorney General for civil rights was principled, courageous and correct.

But it is important to separate the soundness of the decision from the way in which the White House handled the nomination.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Kings Play a Little Traveling Music
nytimes_articles.abstract: Even before the closing arguments were concluded in the Marty McSorley stick-curve case, the Los Angeles Kings were subtly changing the subject, looking to regain a psychological edge against the Montreal Canadiens as their Stanley Cup final series headed back to Los Angeles.   Having split the first two games in Montreal, the teams resume the four-of-seven-game championship round on Saturday night at the other forum, the one located more than 2,500 miles southwest of Montreal.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: Because of an editing error, a news analysis article on Thursday about the Guatemalan political crisis misstated the day of the military ouster of President Jorge Serrano Elias. It was Tuesday, not Monday.

nytimes_articles.headline: Colombian Goalie Higuita Is Arrested
nytimes_articles.abstract: Police in Medellin, Colombia, yesterday arrested one of Latin America's most colorful soccer stars, Colombian national team goalkeeper RENE HIGUITA, on charges of kidnapping and drug trafficking.   The prosecutor-general's office said Higuita, who plays full time for the Medellin team Atletico Nacional, was accused of acting as an intermediary in the freeing of an abducted young woman.

nytimes_articles.headline: Williams Honors Jim Lehrer
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jim Lehrer, associate editor and co-anchor of "The MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour" on PBS, delivered the main address yesterday at the 204th commencement of Williams College in Williamstown, Mass.

nytimes_articles.headline: Germans Arrest 3 More in Bombing Fatal to Turks
nytimes_articles.abstract: The German police have reportedly arrested three men in connection with the fatal firebombing last week at a home occupied by Turks, and say they believe that the bombing was motivated by their anger after having been thrown out of a nearby bar.   Acting on information given by a 16-year-old who was arrested soon after the bombing, the police today arrested another 16-year-old and two men aged 20 and 23. All are believed to have belonged to far-right groups.

nytimes_articles.headline: Guatemala's Vice President Is Said to Resign
nytimes_articles.abstract: Under pressure from the same business, political and social groups that backed the military overthrow of President Jorge Serrano Elias on Tuesday, Mr. Serrano's Vice President renounced his claim to the presidency tonight, politicians said.   The opponents of the Vice President, Gustavo Espina Salguero, effectively turned aside the powerful army leadership, which had surprised and angered many Guatemalans by publicly endorsing Mr. Espina's attempt to take over as President.

nytimes_articles.headline: Gambino Jury Deadlocked
nytimes_articles.abstract: Two reputed mobsters, John and Joseph Gambino, were convicted yesterday only of jumping bail as a jury deadlocked on charges that they distributed thousands of pounds of heroin smuggled into the United States. Judge Peter K. Leisure of Federal District Court in Manhattan declared a mistrial and scheduled a conference for Thursday to discuss a new trial.

nytimes_articles.headline: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: Serbs Feel Invincible; Having Out-Bluffed the West, They May Now Press Their Bosnia Drive
nytimes_articles.abstract: Serbian leaders here and in Bosnia are now acting with increasing confidence, sensing that they have out-bluffed Europe, Russia and the United States, and no longer see any major obstacles to their drive for hegemony in former Yugoslavia.   This is the conclusion of foreign diplomats here and a number of Serbs, who say recent events have made it clear that the major powers have no stomach for direct military intervention in the republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina.

nytimes_articles.headline: Results Plus
nytimes_articles.abstract: COLLEGE BASEBALL Texas A&M Captures World Series Opener Brian Thomas's 15th homer of the season leading off the sixth inning broke a 1-1 tie and helped left-hander Jeff Granger and top-seeded Texas A&M beat Kansas, 5-1, in the opening game of the College World Series yesterday in Omaha. Granger (15-3) scattered five hits and struck out seven in eight innings of work. The Aggies (53-9) move to a game Sunday against L.S.U., which defeated Long Beach State, 7-1, last night. Kansas will play Long Beach in an elimination-bracket game Sunday. (AP) TENNIS Navratilova Advances to Beckenham Final Martina Navratilova avenged a rare grass-court upset yesterday by beating fourth-seeded Linda Harvey-Wild, 6-3, 6-1, in one semifinal match at the Beckenham event in England. Harvey-Wild beat Navratilova in three sets at the Eastbourne tournament last year. Navratilova plays Dutch teen-ager Kristie Boogert in today's final of the exhibition tournament. Boogert, seeded No. 5, beat Kristine Radford, 6-4, 6-2, to gain the final. (AP) GOLF Baker Ties a Record at British Masters Peter Baker of England shot an eight-under 64 yesterday to tie the course record and open a three-stroke lead with a 131 after two rounds of the Dunhill British Masters in Woburn, England. By contrast, British Open champion Nick Faldo ended his round with a 9 on the 18th hole after hitting two drives out of bounds. He finished with a 73 and fell 10 strokes off the lead. Bernhard Langer, who is aiming to add the British Masters title to the Masters he won this spring at Augusta, Ga., shot a second-round 67 and is six strokes off the lead. (AP) Ritzman and King Tie for Lead: A six-stroke swing on the first three holes left Alice Ritzman and Betsy King tied for the lead with 136 totals after two rounds of the Ladies Professional Golf Association Oldsmobile Classic in Meridian Township, Mich. Ritzman, the first-round leader with a six-under-par 66, bogeyed the first three holes at Walnut Hills Country Club, and finished with a 70. King birdied those same holes on her way to her second 68. (AP) TRACK AND FIELD Parilla Takes 2d Straight 800-Meter Title Jose Parilla, a junior at the Univeristy of Tennessee, won the 800 meters for the second straight time in the National Collegiate Athletic Association championships in New Orleans last night. He took the lead from Scott Peters of Florida with 200 meters to go and pulled away to a 4-yard victory in 1 minute 46.51 seconds. Peters held on for second in 1:47.01. Kim Sherman of Wisconsin won the women's 800 by outleaning her teammate, Amy Wickus, 2:02.99 to 2:03.00. Another Badger runner, Clare Eichner, won the women's 3,000 meters in 9:03.06. Lauren Gubicza of Fordham finished third in 9:12.03.

nytimes_articles.headline: Warsaw Journal; Paper's Fare Adds the Spice of Life To Politics and the Poles Devour It
nytimes_articles.abstract: A healthy serving of political analysis, a restaurant critic who can be both caustic and reverential and an elegant color Sunday magazine wrapped around classified advertisements. Does it sound like a well-established American newspaper with a respectable number of readers?   Well, this is Gazeta Wyborcza, the biggest circulation daily in Poland.  Since the fall of the Communist Government four years ago, newspapers and magazines have blossomed in Poland, appealing to virtually every conceivable interest.

nytimes_articles.headline: In Sri Lanka, Negotiation May Yet Prevail
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "In Sri Lanka, Partition Can Stop the Violence" by Rajan Sriskandarajah (letter, May 7) states that the "easiest solution" to the continuing violence in Sri Lanka's northern and eastern provinces is to segregate the Sinhalese and the Tamils by separate self-rule for each area.   This solution may be easy, but it is simplistic. What he argues for is creation of ethnically pure areas in a multiethnic and multireligious society. The professed solution would be tantamount to legitimizing "ethnic cleansing" or "ethnic segregation" on racist lines, which the United Nations and international community have unequivocally rejected, whether in Bosnia or South Africa.

nytimes_articles.abstract: CYNICS say there is no deep meaning to the privatizations that are adding excitement to such diverse equity markets as London, Paris, Prague, and Warsaw. European governments are desperate for cash, goes the argument, and they will seize on any efficient

nytimes_articles.headline: With State Concessions, Pratt & Whitney Accepts Jobs Deal
nytimes_articles.abstract: Pratt & Whitney, Connecticut's largest private employer, said today that it had tentatively agreed not to move 2,300 jobs to plants out of state in return for a package of tax cuts and other incentives.   Company officials said their final decision would be contingent on the state legislature's approval of the package, worth $32 million a year, in the next few days, and on the company's unions agreeing to concessions of about the same amount, or about $2 an hour.

nytimes_articles.headline: Haitian Rulers Are Target of New Sanctions by U.S.
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a tacit acknowledgment that its diplomacy has failed to restore Haiti's democratically elected Government, the Clinton Administration today imposed sanctions on supporters of the military-backed Government and said it would begin consultations on further economic measures, including a possible oil embargo.   Administration officials said the assets in the United States of 83 individuals and 35 institutions would be frozen, including cash accounts, real estate and other property. They will also be blocked from any financial transactions in the United States, and the individuals and members of their families will be barred from entering the country.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mets and Tanana Cave In Under the Astros' Roof
nytimes_articles.abstract: The formula for success against Frank Tanana is to balance patience with aggression. The deal is to wait for the moment of opportunity and then not waste a second seizing it.   It's a formula that can't be followed any more perfectly than the Houston Astros did tonight in beating the Mets, 7-2, at the Astrodome.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hartford Bill on Integration Is Approved
nytimes_articles.abstract: A bill promoting racial integration in public schools across Connecticut won final approval tonight in the State Senate.   Although weakened by its supporters to win passage, the bill is a significant step toward addressing the issue of segregated schools, by requiring the state's cities and towns to participate in regional talks and offering financial incentives if they create schools that draw students across municipal boundaries.

nytimes_articles.headline: As Bosnia Burns, More Bluster, Impotence and Vanity
nytimes_articles.abstract: - Five smiling foreign ministers faced the world's cameras on May 22 and claimed that the "Russian" plan for Bosnia promised a process that would lead to a just peace. Yet recent days have seen some of the fiercest fighting of the war. So much for Balkan promises.

nytimes_articles.headline: Religion Notes
nytimes_articles.abstract: Studying Lifting a Ban   Contrary to official policy, girls serve as, well, altar boys in many Catholic parishes around the United States, helping priests at mass with tasks like distributing the communion bread. Now there is talk that the Vatican may lift the prohibition against girls serving at the altar.

nytimes_articles.headline: Clerk Is Charged in Courthouse Killing
nytimes_articles.abstract: An employee of Superior Court was charged today with smuggling into the courthouse here a gun that was used to kill a police officer just before he was scheduled to testify at a drug trial.   Clifford J. Minor, the Essex County Prosecutor, identified the gun smuggler as Tinesha James, 22, a clerk-typist in the probation department and the girlfriend of a defendant in the drug case. Mr. Minor said the young woman entered the building on Thursday through an employee's entrance, wearing a jacket belonging to the man accused in the shooting and hiding his .357 Magnum in her waistband. Meanwhile, the man passed through one of the metal detectors that guard all public entrances to the 12-story building.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article last Saturday comparing President Clinton's job aproval rating with that of his predecessors mischaracterized the timing of a Gallup poll taken in August 1945. That poll, in which 92 percent of those surveyed approved of the way Harry S. Truman was handling his job as President, was taken several months after the German surrender and two weeks after the Japanese surrender, not several months after the end of World War II.

nytimes_articles.headline: Chi Chi Putts-Putts Into the Picture
nytimes_articles.abstract: After shooting his best round in eight tournaments with help from an old putter he found in the bagroom at Sleepy Hollow Country Club, Chi Chi Rodriguez, one of golf's biggest rib-ticklers, announced today he has been playing with a broken rib for the last five weeks.   "I broke the rib falling in an airplane," Rodriguez said. "I couldn't sue anybody because it was my own plane."

nytimes_articles.headline: In Statues of Women, Numbers Aren't the Story; For Mrs. Roosevelt
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Further on your May 23 editorial about the lack of public sculptures of women in New York City, please note that the Eleanor Roosevelt Monument Fund has been working since 1986 to place a statue of Mrs. Roosevelt in Riverside Park at 72d Street and also to rehabilitate two acres of deteriorated parkland.

nytimes_articles.headline: Judge Reverses 3 Convictions In Gang Cases
nytimes_articles.abstract: After working for more than 20 years to smash El Rukns, one of the city's most powerful street gangs, local and Federal prosecutors reveled in their victory over the gang two years ago, when dozens of El Rukns and their associates were convicted or pleaded guilty on the testimony of gang leaders turned Government witness.    But today, in a blistering 137-page decision, a Federal judge granted three of the defendants a new trial, citing a long and "disturbing" list of prosecutorial misconduct. The three defendants, Tom Burnside, Codell Griffin and C. D. Jackson, were not members of El Rukns but were convicted of supplying the gang with drugs.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sun Close to Setting on England for '94 Cup
nytimes_articles.abstract: ALAN ROTHENBERG, chief executive of World Cup '94, called England's precarious qualifying situation for next year's Cup, which will be played in the United States, a "mixed blessing." He said yesterday at a news conference in Manhattan that the absence of the English would diminish the threat from hooligans but could also eliminate tradition.   "When people think about the thugs, unfortunately they think about England," Rothenberg said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Anatomy of the Failure To Confirm a Nominee
nytimes_articles.abstract: While President Clinton and virtually every member of his senior staff spent last week intent on getting the Administration's budget bill passed, storm clouds were gathering over Lani Guinier's nomination to head the Justice Department's civil rights division. They were ignored.   But by the time the President met with Ms. Guinier for more than an hour on Thursday evening, several officials had told him that she could not be confirmed by the Senate.

nytimes_articles.headline: BRIEFCASE: U.S. Newsletter 'Patrols' The Streets of New Funds
nytimes_articles.abstract: With U.S. investors showing no signs of a letup in the millions of dollars they are pumping into mutual funds, money managers are racing to roll out dozens of funds each month. Now, one publisher is taking advantage of the heated competition with the laun

nytimes_articles.headline: For Stephanopoulos, Power's Within Reach
nytimes_articles.abstract: If access is power, George Stephanopoulos has not been pushed as far out of the loop as initial information may have indicated.   The floor plans on the White House shakeup are out, and Mr. Stephanopoulos, who is now senior adviser to the President, will take over office space now occupied by Nancy Hernreich, the President's personal secretary. The office, while smaller than Mr. Stephanopoulos's current capacious digs, has the advantage of direct access to the Oval Office and the President's private dining room.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Lani Guinier Mess
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton's nomination and subsequent rejection of Lani Guinier to head the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division has been an unmitigated mess for the White House. Ms. Guinier, in interviews defending herself, has at least shown considerable grace and courage; she is a serious individual who conducted herself well under enormous pressure. Mr. Clinton, by contrast, has appeared either inept in choosing nominees or unwilling to fight when challenged.   Although he handled the nomination miserably, the President had good reason to drop it. Ms. Guinier's writings suggest that, despite her obvious talents as a civil rights attorney, she was not the right person to be Washington's civil rights enforcement chief. Mr. Clinton, already wobbling from other setbacks, had no stomach for a fight he couldn't win on behalf of a candidate whose views he now says he does not entirely endorse.

nytimes_articles.headline: BRIEFCASE: Citibank Launches Vehicle In Marks for Futures Trade
nytimes_articles.abstract: Citibank is launching a new fund, aimed at European investors, which it describes as "a globally diversified, three-year term, actively managed investment vehicle, with guaranteed return of original investment.". The World Futures vehicle is a l

nytimes_articles.headline: Fernandez Looks for One More Upset
nytimes_articles.abstract: Unless ennui should get the better of Steffi Graf as she gets down to business in her 19th Grand Slam final on Saturday, and it rarely does, the 23-year-old German seems poised to collect her 12th Grand Slam title. She hasn't, after all, ever lost a match to Mary Joe Fernandez, the only obstacle between herself and a third French Open title.   Graf, who hasn't won the title here since 1988, would appear to have the upper hand when she marches onto center court at Roland Garros with her newly regained No. 1 ranking. She has reached a final 96 times in her career, 86 times more than Fernandez has. And she has won 11 Grand Slam tournaments, while Fernandez, in two previous finals, both in Australia, has come up empty.

nytimes_articles.headline: New Snag in Folk Art Museum's Hunt for a Home
nytimes_articles.abstract: On and off again for a dozen years, the plan to build a permanent home for the Museum of American Folk Art at the base of a new office tower in mid-Manhattan now seems to be unraveling.   An affiliate of Investcorp, the international investment bank that was once a partner in the development project, has moved to foreclose the mortgage on four of six vacant brownstones owned by the museum on West 53d Street, said Ralph Esmerian, the president of the museum's board.

nytimes_articles.headline: Across the Country, Public Access TV Gives Free Speech Form
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   I strongly disagree with the observation in your May 23 article about TCI Cable of New York's Westchester County and public access television that public access is for the most part "sometimes amateurish entertainment and often lifeless talk, with a handful of compelling programs." The value of successful access programming goes beyond those traditional measures. The local church choir is not the technical equivalent of the Mormon Tabernacle Choir, but that doesn't keep us from appreciating the joy of a community coming together to raise its voice in song.   TCI Cable of Westchester has long been a vocal supporter of our access channels. The fringe group programs you cite were indeed hateful, but they do not represent the majority of programming on these channels. nytimes_articles.abstract: The prize, the Musketeers Cup, is crafted of sterling silver, but two-time French Open champion Jim Courier is continuing to play unvarnished lunch-pail tennis in his effort to do what no other American man has done by claiming the trophy a third time. nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Dance; For the Joyce's 10th Birthday, a Hearty Party
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Joyce Theater gave itself a birthday party on Tuesday night in celebration of its 10th anniversary, complete with balloons, eloquent speeches and a fast-forward jaunt through contemporary dance. It is hard to remember New York dance without the Joyce. It has played an invaluable role as a well-appointed, welcoming home for middle-sized dance companies who have outgrown theaters like Dance Theater Workshop and Performance Space 122 but are not yet ready for City Center. The Joyce has also developed a new and faithful audience for dance. All that was hard to imagine a decade ago, when Cora Cahan and Eliot Feld, then administrator and choreographer of the Feld Ballet, looked at the Elgin, a rundown neighborhood movie house, and imagined the Joyce.    Ms. Cahan and Mr. Feld were on hand to talk of that decade on Tuesday, along with Linda Shelton, director of the Joyce, and Kitty Carlisle Hart, the head of the New York State Council on the Arts and a spirited early believer in the theater. A seat, K 108, has now been named for Miss Hart. Then it was time for dancing, in an impressively staged but rather dizzying succession of works performed by nine individuals and groups.

nytimes_articles.headline: The City Budget: Still Gimmicky
nytimes_articles.abstract: With a bow to reality, Mayor David Dinkins and his advisers have revised the New York City budget. nytimes_articles.headline: Sorting Out the Medical Claims Jumble
nytimes_articles.abstract: A family of five can generate dozens of medical insurance claims in a year. Just ask Barbara and David Blumenthal, who at one point this year accumulated a pile of unpaid claims for doctor visits, lab tests, outpatient procedures and regular checkups for themselves and their three children.   With their medical coverage split between two insurers, Phoenix Home Life and Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, the Blumenthals were not sure which bills were covered and whether they were being paid fairly for claims.   "I had lost track of what was outstanding," Mrs. Blumenthal said. "All I knew was that I was missing a lot of money.   Like many two-career couples, the Blumenthals are pressed for time. Both run importing businesses and juggle responsibilities at their home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.   Overwhelmed by the paperwork, Mrs. Blumenthal acted on a friend's recommendation and hired a medical claims agent. Such agents are accustomed to dealing with insurance companies and can handle all the filings and follow-up calls. They also know how and when to challenge insurers over a rejected claim or a paltry reimbursement, say, $15 for a $100 office visit.   Since hiring their insurance go-between, the Blumenthals have received $3,000 in previously unpaid claims and paid the agent $575 in fees, including a $120 annual retainer.   Other families, the chronically ill, the elderly and even some companies are turning to medical claims agents to sort through the maze of insurance red tape. These agents can handle the paperwork arising from a catastrophic illness, address a backlog of claims or be a consultant on retainer.   People in the fledgling industry operate under several names: medical billing agents, public health adjusters and medical insurance consultants. The businesses are so new that there is no classification for them in the Yellow Pages. And they are not licensed or regulated in most states, including New York, which means consumers should check references carefully before selecting an agent.   Even their trade organization, the National Association of Claims Assistance Professionals of Downers Grove, Ill., is only two years old. "People still don't know we exist," said Norma Border, the association's national director. The association, which has 800 members, puts the number of adjusters nationwide at 3,000 to 6,000, and expects business to continue growing even if the Clinton Administration overhauls the nation's health-care system.   Gila Bash Katz, who is the Blumenthals' agent, has enlisted 46 regular clients and one small company, which pays her to handle its employees' claims, since founding Quick Claims Inc. of Eastchester, N.Y., two years ago.   After initial contact, the adjuster will likely agree to make a house call, at no charge, to discuss your claims situation. If you decide to proceed, you will need to sign a limited power of attorney giving the professional the authority to deal directly with the insurance company. The claims adjuster will also need copies of all medical insurance contracts.   The agent's fees may be structured in several ways: a percentage, usually 10 to 15 percent, of the reimbursed amount; an hourly charge of $25 to $55; a specified amount for each claim, or an annual fee.   Rarely do adjusters set a minimum fee, although clients say it is seldom worth signing up until you have amassed at least $2,000 in contested or delayed claims. Threatening letters from hospitals and doctors who have not been paid often send consumers to a medical adjuster.   For the Blumenthals, the medical claims agent has taken on the status of the family lawyer or accountant, handling all medical insurance paperwork and providing advice on related matters. The family permits Ms. Katz to cash its insurance checks, deduct her 15 percent fee and consolidate the smaller reimbursements into a single check. But others may prefer to pay the agent separately.   The elderly, many of whom are covered by Medicare and a supplementary private policy, may look for a claims adjuster familiar with the vagaries of overlapping policies. The Berryhill Medical Claims Service of Danbury, Conn., says about 80 percent of its clients are covered by Medicare and a Medigap policy.    Ursula Milde, director of an elderly outreach program for New Rochelle Hospital in Westchester County, regularly sends people to adjusters. "I see people who don't know what to send where anymore," she said. "You need itemized bills. You may need to make copies. You must know what's in your policy if they try to reject your claim."    Insurance companies are only beginning to become familiar with medical claims adjusters, and insist it is too soon to gauge their effectiveness. But reimbursement is not necessarily quicker, cautioned John Gras, a spokesman for the Prudential-AARP Group Health Insurance.   Still, finding an intermediary to handle insurance headaches has its appeal. Even the Mellon Bank of Pittsburgh has hired a medical adjuster, Claim Guard Plus of Indianapolis, to assist its trust clients. "The volume of paperwork and the number of clients got too high," said Marylee Steinmetz, supervisor of the trust insurance unit.

nytimes_articles.headline: Older but Still Hip, the Velvet Underground Rocks Again
nytimes_articles.abstract: The New Musical Express, Britain's leading pop-music weekly, indulged its taste for puns by headlining its cover story "The Revival of the Hippest." The Independent, a London daily, contented itself with "the comeback to end all comebacks." Whatever you called it, the reunion of the Velvet Underground this week at the Edinburgh Playhouse -- with a European tour, a live album and no doubt more to come -- was very big news indeed.   Not bad for three men over 50 and a 48-year-old mother of five. What made the excitement all the odder was that during its brief existence (1965 to 1968, in this configuration), the Velvet Underground sold hardly any records at all. Hostile to peace-and-love banalities, irreducibly New York in attitude, the band epitomized the coolness of the downtown Manhattan art scene and the sex-and-drugs danger of the city at night. Division, Then Reunion    Ignored or reviled by the American public and the record industry, the Velvets still had an enormous influence, especially when they were taken up by Andy Warhol and given a temporary new lead singer in Nico, his latest "superstar." Blending Lou Reed's adult poetry with John Cale's vanguard musical experimentation, the Velvets were the parents of the entire art rock, punk, new-wave and college rock scenes worldwide.   Bitterness kept the Velvets apart. Mr. Reed had forced Mr. Cale out in 1968 and embarked on his solo career in 1970. Sterling Morrison, who had been a college classmate of Mr. Reed's at Syracuse University, wouldn't talk to his old friend for years, until a new band contract was signed in 1986, redistributing record royalties.   Mr. Reed was the only one to sustain a visible career. Mr. Cale made and produced some admired records, but his most notable recent achievement was a 1988 commemoration of Warhol, in collaboration with Mr. Reed, called "Songs for Drella." Maureen Tucker, the band's drummer, lived in Georgia, brought up her children, worked in the computer business and played in underground bands. Mr. Morrison eventually earned a Ph.D. in English literature in Texas, working on tugboats in the Gulf of Mexico and playing in Ms. Tucker's latest band. Nico was killed in a bicycle accident in Ibiza in 1988.   In 1990, at the invitation of the Cartier Foundation, the four surviving band members got together in Paris for a Warhol tribute. That led to a quasi-impromptu public rendition of one of their most famous songs, "Heroin," but was no proper reunion. For that, another meeting in New York, followed by two days of trial-run practice sessions, was necessary before the current European tour got the go-ahead.   The watchword for the reunion is fun. Band members have used the word in many interviews, and while it may be their actual motivating factor, it is also a conscious strategy to subvert cosmic expectations. The problem with a Velvet Underground reunion is that nothing the band will do can match the legend that has grown up around it. As David Sinclair wrote on Monday in The Times of London, "The group's unique godhead status will begin to diminish almost from the moment they start their first number." Fun and Money    Clearly their ambitions are serious, and include the courting of a mass audience that was never theirs in the 1960's. The first big concert takes place tomorrow at the 13,000-seat Wembley Arena in London, with four stadium dates with the Irish band U2 at the end of the month and an appearance at the huge Glastonbury Festival in England on July 25. All of this for a band that never played in Europe.   The four musicians say they have no plans for further activity, but they surely have expectations. An album to be recorded live in Paris from June 15 to 17 will be released by Sire, presumably to coordinate with American performances. The issue is not whether the band will perform in the United States, but when and under what circumstances. "We're all going our separate ways," Mr. Reed said in a group interview between shows in Edinburgh. "But if anything came up and it seemed very special and it seemed like fun, we'd be receptive."   This will mean money, which most of the band members can use. But all four seem sufficiently aware of -- proud of, burdened by, amused at -- their legend not to wish it squandered out of simple greed. They insist they reunited only because they became convinced that their material still held up, still made sense and could still be played best by them. Above all, they resented being intimidated by their own reputation. "Should we stay in hiding just because a myth is loose in the land?" Mr. Morrison asked.   No attempt has been made to recreate the exact sound of the old, technically primitive recordings. New equipment lends the band's sound a solidity and variety it never had before. Sylvia Reed, Mr. Reed's wife and manager, is now the Velvets' manager and the designer of their contemporary-looking stage lighting. Mr. Cale has fretted about looking and sounding too slick.   At rehearsals, they relearned the words and musical structures of the old songs and then developed them at will. (Mr. Cale had to learn songs created after his departure; he also now sings a couple of Nico favorites.)   "We never played them the same way twice back then, so why should we now?" Mr. Reed asked. As Mr. Cale has said, "We're in the business of remythologizing, not demythologizing." Although repertory for this tour consists basically of old band material, they are gingerly working in some new numbers, including a most effective -- and inescapably Velvet Undergroundish -- item called "Cast the First Stone" as the third and final encore Thursday night. Building Enthusiasm    British critics have so far been mixed in their reactions, "Cleaning up their act seems like cheating," one wrote before he had heard a note. Another came right out and argued that since the members of Velvet Underground had purveyed death, they should have died, long ago. But others seemed more impressed then they had expected to be.   "The language the Velvet Underground invented still communicates the rock 'n' roll verities," wrote the critic for The Glasgow Herald. Mr. Sinclair, in The Times of London, seemed to recant his earlier pessimism: "This show did not produce a feeling of deja vu," he wrote on Thursday, "more an impression that, after 25 years, the rest of the world has only just caught up with them."   Those who attended both Edinburgh shows found the second, on Thursday, far superior to the first. Nervousness had receded, and the band was beginning to generate an excitement that will surely build over the tour. Certainly the audience loved it, standing throughout the two-hour set and cheering wildly.   Indeed, there was much to cheer. Mr. Reed still sings with the same ominous distinctiveness; Mr. Cale is still the same multi-faceted musical saboteur; Mr. Morrison still contributes a guitar sound of weight and solidity. The revelation on Thursday, though, was the diminutive Ms. Tucker's drumming. Standing at her kit and whacking away, she makes a tom-toms-of-doom sound that inspired straight-ahead punk drumming for a generation. The effect is not quirky or amateurish; it is rocklike in the granitic sense of that word, the foundation on which the band could build a creative future to match its potently nostalgic past.

nytimes_articles.headline: North Korea Isn't Convinced It Should Stay in Nuclear Pact
nytimes_articles.abstract: United States negotiators failed again today to persuade North Korea to drop its plans to withdraw next week from an international treaty intended to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.   Expressing disappointment at the outcome of the talks, the State Department said in a statement tonight that North Korea had "showed no willingness to meet most of our concerns and those of the international community."

nytimes_articles.headline: British Chief, Under Fire, Declares, 'I'm Staying'
nytimes_articles.abstract: Clearly irritated by a growing chorus of critics who say he is not up to the job, Prime Minister John Major offered a fighting defense of his Government today, telling an audience of Conservative Party women: "I am fit. I am well. I am here -- and I'm staying."   In departing from the prepared text of his speech, the Prime Minister lashed out after a series of recent reports in British papers that cited anonymous sources and unidentified ministers who described Mr. Major lost in a fog of gloom and depression as a result of declining public confidence in his leadership and faltering Tory morale.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Testing and Tiring Two-Week Marathon for Jordan
nytimes_articles.abstract: Michael Jordan looked tired last night. Tired, and frustrated by being harassed by the Knicks, nagged by the press and haunted by skeletons from his closet. He missed just about everything he threw up in the second half. He lashed out, Knick style, at Doc Rivers for nothing more than being played hard. It was almost two long weeks for basketball's Superman, who was shown to be vulnerable, if not beatable, by the Knicks.   "I thought Michael was exhausted tonight," said Bulls Coach Phil Jackson. "I think there was a tremendous strain with all the controversy."

nytimes_articles.headline: Broadway Box Office Registers A Big Rise
nytimes_articles.abstract: Broadway theatergoers spent a total of $327.7 million at the box office in the 1992-93 season, according to figures made public yesterday by the League of American Theaters and Producers, the Broadway trade group, which says the sum is the highest ever. The figure was $34.7 million higher than last season's box office tally, which held the previous record.    Attendance was also up 477,000 over last year, for a year-end total of 7.9 million. But there were fewer new productions this year (33, compared with 37 last season), and attendance did not come close to the 11 million admissions in the early 1980's, when there were many more shows.

nytimes_articles.headline: Observer; The Rain In Spain Stays . . .
nytimes_articles.abstract: Instructions for a President:   1. Know thyself. You may not have peaked too soon, but you have certainly peaked very young. A man elected President at age 46 will be a mere 54 when he loses the job. That's if he is lucky. If he is not, the best job he can ever have will be over and done with when he is 50. Nowadays 54 is young and 50 is very young.    2. Act on this self-knowledge. In short, this is the whole ball game, right here and right now. After this, all else will be small cheese unless you think spending the final 30 or 40 years of your life reading history's judgments will be tons of fun. You must do something to make the historians respect you. Quit dawdling and do it now.

nytimes_articles.abstract: Picture yourself as a Nobel Prize winner who is forced into house arrest because of your political beliefs. It turns out that DAW AUNG SAN SUU KYI, the confined opposition political leader in Myanmar who was awarded the 1991 Nobel Peace Prize, chose the Encyclopedia Britannica.

nytimes_articles.headline: Baffling Epidemic Gripping Navajos' Land of Mysteries
nytimes_articles.abstract: In this land of swaggering sky and wind-carved red sandstone, where the black tongues of ancient lava flows still stain the pale plateau and the sediments everywhere are freckled with dinosaur fossils, imagination and mystery have an easy foothold.   But perhaps never before has a mystery held the Navajo Nation and surrounding towns in such a tight vise as has the devastating flu-like illness that has swept through the Four Corners region of New Mexico and Arizona, killing 11 people and gravely sickening at least seven others.

nytimes_articles.headline: Clinton Tries to Cut Losses After Abandoning a Choice
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton today set about trying to deal with the political damage from his decision to drop Lani Guinier as his choice to be the Justice Department's new civil rights chief. But she remained defiant, saying the President did not understand her theories and should have given her a chance to explain them to the Senate.    Mr. Clinton sought especially to soothe new political irritations in his relationship with members of the Congressional Black Caucus, who were among the most angered at his decision to abandon the Guinier nomination in the face of mounting Senate criticism of her proposals to increase the political power of black voters.

nytimes_articles.headline: Election of a Bishop Divides Episcopalians
nytimes_articles.abstract: If, as the saying goes, religion and politics don't mix, it might well follow that the nastiest of politics often involve the church itself.   There may be no better example than in the Episcopal Diocese of Connecticut, in a church with a long and distinguished reputation for civility, in which a six-way contest to select a bishop has turned into a free-for-all with charges and countercharges, suspicions and rumors.

nytimes_articles.abstract: DONALD J. TRUMP finally got his way yesterday when the town council of Palm Beach, Fla., voted 4 to 1 to approve the planned conversion of his 140-room home, Mar-a-Lago, into a beach club and health spa.   Mr. Trump originally planned to subdivide the property, which faces both the ocean and the Intracoastal Waterway and was formerly the home of the Post cereal heiress, Marjorie Merriweather Post. But in deference to the town and to his wealthy neighbors he decided instead to convert it to a private club.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: PHIL DONAHUE has been known to dance around a guest or two in his more than 25 years as a talk-show host. But now he is doing a bit of hoofing for real.   On Monday evening, he and seven schoolchildren from 8 to 12 years old will perform a tap-dance routine of "Me and My Shadow" as part of the annual recital and benefit for the National Dance Institute. The event will be held at the Paramount at Madison Square Garden.

nytimes_articles.headline: Commentator Criticizes NBC
nytimes_articles.abstract: NBC's Peter Vecsey last night rebuked the network for giving broad coverage to accusations by a compulsive gambler and friend of Michael Jordan who alleged that Jordan ran up golf debts with him totaling $1.25 million. The accusations were contained in book by the gambler, Richard Esquinas.   "It was an embarrassment to the media, to NBC especially," said Vecsey, one of NBC's group of studio insiders for National Basketball Association games. "Personally, I'd have never gone on with a story like that." He added: "We were irresponsible. I think that the guy's motives were clear. He's a publicity seeker. He's looking to make financial gain and we gave a story of no importance credibility."

nytimes_articles.headline: Weather Becomes a Factor in Belmont
nytimes_articles.abstract: Along the backstretch on the eve of the 125th Belmont Stakes, trainers were scanning the skies for the approach of rain yesterday, and some were predicting that rain was one chance factor that could tilt the balance.   Nobody can sweep the Triple Crown this year because Sea Hero won the Kentucky Derby five weeks ago and Prairie Bayou won the Preakness two weeks later. But both horses still have shots at the $1 million bonus for best performance in the series, depending on how they run in the Belmont, the third and most punishing race.

nytimes_articles.headline: 4 Youths Arrested in Killing of Bicyclist in Park
nytimes_articles.abstract: Four Brooklyn teen-agers were arrested yesterday in the fatal shooting of a drama teacher who had fought off their efforts to steal his $250 bicycle on a wooded dirt trail in Prospect Park, the police said.   The youths -- two 14 and two 16 -- had a simple motive, the police said, when they attacked the teacher, Allyn Winslow, on Tuesday: three of them had bikes and they wanted a fourth.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sports of The Times; The Issue Is Bigger Than Jordan
nytimes_articles.abstract: ACCORDING to Richard Esquinas, a San Diego businessman turned author, Michael Jordan took the floor last night for Game 6 against the Knicks owing Esquinas $100,000 in golf gambling debts.   In his book, titled "Michael & Me: Our Gambling Addiction . . . My Cry For Help!" Esquinas, who owns the company that published the book, claims that Jordan has paid $200,000 but still owes $100,000 as settlement of a debt that reached more than $1 million. Esquinas said he finally reduced the debt to $300,000 because he was convinced Jordan would not pay the entire amount.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sihanouk Is Blaming His Son for Collapse of Coalition
nytimes_articles.abstract: Struggling to explain how his coalition government had collapsed only hours after its creation, Prince Norodom Sihanouk made clear today that he placed the blame for the debacle on his 49-year-old son, the leader of the opposition political party that won last week's internationally supervised Cambodian elections.   United Nations peacekeepers said it was still likely that Prince Sihanouk, Cambodia's ceremonial head of state and its former monarch, would form some sort of coalition government. The Prince, who has a reputation for being unpredictable, has changed his mind before.

nytimes_articles.abstract:
Someone recently said to me: "There is something wrong with Japanese society. Children study too much; university students play too much; wage earners work too much, and retired persons have too much leisure. Everything in excess."

Although Japanese society may look rosy -- we have peace, low unemployment and low crime -- there is definitely a lack of balance.

nytimes_articles.headline: Reaching a Decision in the New Yorker Trial: a Juror's Account
nytimes_articles.abstract: Rather than judging the journalistic techniques of Janet Malcolm or the amorous history of Jeffrey M. Masson, the Federal jury at their libel trial focused on a precise and painstaking form of detective work, a juror said today: figuring out whether five quotations in Ms. Malcolm's articles about him were made up and then whether the fabrication was accidental or deliberate.   The monthlong trial ended on Thursday, when the eight jurors deadlocked over how much money to award Mr. Masson. But the juror's account made clear how much they agreed on and how they decided that two of the five quotations were not just made up but libelous.

nytimes_articles.headline: ESPN 2 Ready For Prime Time
nytimes_articles.abstract: ESPN will unveil on Monday the full details of ESPN 2, a second cable sports network designed to be heavy on sports news, to appeal to a young audience and to be the home of National Hockey League games.   ESPN 2, which will debut in the fall, has been in the works for some time. Its formal unveiling has been delayed while the company spent considerable time working out agreements with cable systems to carry the service.

nytimes_articles.headline: In Statues of Women, Numbers Aren't the Story
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   The point of "Statues, With Limitations" (editorial, May 23), on the quantitative discrepancy between statues of men and of women in New York City can be conceded, with a view to future increase in the number of women. Yet you do not sufficiently recognize the artistic excellence and symbolic importance of the female figure in the city's statuary.   The decision of the sculptor of the Statue of Liberty, Frederic A. Bartholdi, to depict the theme of "Liberty Enlightening the World" for the centennial of both the American and the French revolutions with a woman holding a lamp, has had significance for American cultural attitudes. One bit of evidence is the response found in the Emma Lazarus inscription.

pages.title: Scarborough, North Yorkshire
pages.abstract: Scarborough is a seaside town in the district and county of North Yorkshire, England. It is located on the North Sea coastline. Historically in the North Riding of Yorkshire, the town lies between 10 and 230 feet above sea level, from the harbour rising steeply north and west towards limestone cliffs. The older part of the town lies around the harbour and is protected by a rocky headland.
